data.title: Grow old along with me the best is yet to be
data.meta_description: Good day.  The text .  Grow old along with me! The best is yet to be.  Is the beginning of a poem by Robert Frost.  It has been a favoirte of my wife and I...
data.text:
I think 'really?' is a way of saying: it is a surprise that anyone should recommend this translation in this way, not only because it is wrong, but also because announcing that it came off the notoriously inaccurate Google translate is like waving a red flag in front of a bull, as far as this website is concerned, so that one has to wonder whether the suggestion was made in earnest; but some days one just can't find the energy to do more than raise the eyebrows.

So: senescere is the infinitive, and we need some form that can convey a suggestion/command/exhortation. Thus, either senesce, or senescito (as previously suggested) or senescas. Then optima futura is not so much wrong as elliptical -- one is meant to understand 'optima futura sunt', I suppose. That sort of thing is technically possible, as a general rule, but it feels out of place here stylistically, and the implied change of subject is awkward; so that the two halves don't feel as if they have been conceived as part of the same sentiment, but are just glued together regardless.

Yes, it's Browning.

Look sir, I do not formally speak Latim and that is why I'm here on this forum. To learn.

The google translation was better than "nam secunda contingent futura". This doesn't make sense to me at all as "the best is yet to be".
